ratings.question_text: What is your overall assessment of this course?

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize AFAM 505 01/AMST 643 01 for a fellow student? Would you recommend AFAM 505 01/AMST 643 01 to another student? Why or why not?
comments: Very good and entertaining course. Reviews many concepts that need to be seen for microeconomics and business in general and helps you understand them more. The cases are very relevant and the topic selection is as well. It has inspired on me a bew passion on social business in developing countries.
I recommend this course especially for the economic students who want to know the application of the economic theories in practice.
Very good way of seeing economic theories being applied to contexts of developing countries.
Thorough discussions of various market failures and strategies for negotiating them. I would recommend it for both public and private sector-oriented students.
Excellent class for anyone on the public or private side interested in working in developing countries.

The class provides an effective introduction to the economic forces underlying the common challenges facing firms operating in developing contexts; with a greater use of case studies, the course could more thoroughly allow students to understand firm's potential response to those challenges.

This course gives a helpful introduction to the challenges of conducting business abroad, the economic rationales behind institutions commonly found in developing economies, and some of the reasons these countries face the problems they do.I would recommend it with the caveats expressed above about the sometimes perplexing/poor management of the course.
I would recommend this course to students interested in the subject matter.
I wouldn't particularly recommend the course.
Great course for those interested in the use of economics to further development and understand its impediments.

narratives.question_text: How did this course deepen your knowledge of your discipline/profession? To what extent did this course contribute to your dissertation/research?
comments: I do not have an Econ background and as an undergrad I tried the course in order to see if I would be interested in business in the future. It has done it.

As a military officer, I was interested in learning about economic challenges in the developing world and the extent to which they affect long-term security and stability. I thinkthe course addressed these well, and I would recommend it to other students with similar objectives/interests.

This course effectively introduced me to some of the fundamental economic forces underlying the common challenges facing firms in developing countries, which I expect with have some practical, professional applications for me in the years ahead.
This course was not directly linked to my discipline, though I think that some of the strategies presented may help with my future work.
Not as significantly as I would've hoped.
